title: Husky...Forever So(2011)[FLAC]
description:

ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s a familiar story Ã¢â‚¬â€œ men with beards playing vintage instruments and writing folk songs in isolated Ã¢â‚¬ËœrusticÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ locations. ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s almost an initiation rite if you want kudos for your folk chops, and Melbourne four-piece Husky are no exception, their debut record Forever So the result of a comparable backstory. Based around the songs of singer/guitarist Husky Gawenda and keyboardist Gideon Preiss, the band tread a path similar to Fleet Foxes, reaching back to the likes of Fairport Convention and adding in the odd touch of Beach Boys (see, for example, GawendaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Carl Wilson impression at the end of The Woods). While I had initially expected another poor-manÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Fleet Foxes imitation, I found myself drawn to much of Forever So. Beautiful little moments litter the record, instances that grab you and demand attention Ã¢â‚¬â€œ such as how the finger-picked guitar gives way to the rich intonation of Gawenda during the opening stanzas of the impressive HistoryÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Door; the gentle Midlake-like vocal harmonies that drift through Hunter, and the compelling tale of frayed relationships that lurks beneath Dark Sea. HuskyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s stories are certainly romanticised, but this type of music works best that way and Husky have the approach down pat. ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s not all plain sailing though Ã¢â‚¬â€œ the first half of the record is noticeably stronger than the second, the mood changing somewhere around the title track, the songs becoming more self-conscious and less charming. Tracks like the sympathetic How Do You Feel are not necessarily bad, but lack the immediacy of those that come before. Still, I expected to dislike Forever So, but ended up largely enjoying it. Meaning HuskyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s music may be powerful enough to win over the sceptics.
